important stories that are very formative for the earlier parts of the old testament and we refresh our minds on some of that stuff and now we're more clear on all the whole narrative of the whole thing hangs together worst case scenario worst case scenario best case scenario we just got a pretty good look at who this guy's descended from and what this very high steaks age old rivalry is between the jewish people and the agigites or the amalekites and if it is the latter then what we're getting here is something where the original audience would hit chapter three and they would see this part and they see the name agag and they'd be like this is a story about unfinished business there's a fight happen back in the desert wilderness wanderings during the exodus and then there was after that after a whole bunch of more injustices and attempts to commit genocide against the hebrew people then there was another incident where god was like it's time for me to pronounce my judgment against this rival people so that this threat will be eliminated i know how harsh that sounds but you're talking about a different world back then and you're talking about very high steaks in terms of relationships between neighbors like this and the descendants of the amalekites and the well the amalekites and the descendants of agag it made it really clear now you years are people group that we would love to just do away with completely so it comes time for their judgment day there to get it sol is god's chosen instrument and all of that hard for me to even say these words because again i live in such a totally different moral cultural context but that's what the bible holds out and then saw imitates their behavior and tries to take plunder from them in defiance of god's will defiance of gods instructions and in doing so he makes it look like just another little squabble another border dispute from the long distant past that any outsider would look at and be like this wasn't a justified at all is just a tit for tat squabble between greedy people which is what i think we are tempted to do with it right now right i mean the cynical reader the old testament is going to look back on that and the looks like you probably just wanted your neighbors gold and it's just two different groups of one of their neighbors gold and then the winners wrote history so because of the way we react to it this early all these centuries later it almost kind of vindicates gods anger it's all afterwards for debasing the whole affair and making it about something or making it look like it was about something different than it was actually about but back to this unfinished business theme if indeed haman is an agigite descended from king agag who saw did not properly defeat according to the wishes of god some five hundred plus years before the events recorded in the book of ester took place then the original audience to look at this and be like uh... okay i get it this is another one of those stories where the failures of our ancestors to obey god now comes home to roost and so the question is is this going to be a story about how those failures result in another round of judgment for gods people we know we have a common or is this going to be a situation where god flexes the muscles of his faithfulness and delivers us in contrast to our historic faith lessness all that stuff i just said is assuming that this is best to be understood as haman being a descendant of agag and therefore an amalekite the age old enemy of the jewish people however as we are in the habit of doing in our conversations i have to acknowledge another thread of thought that exists regarding the ethnic background of haman and that is that he is not literally descended from the amalekites at all he's not literally descended from agag at all there are very smart very good people who read this text a little differently than what to me feels like the obvious read and they would say no we would point to evidence that agag here agagite here at the time of ester it's a metaphor for any anti-semite anybody who wants to destroy the jewish people they kind of took on the same so i can the same way that julia caesar lent his name to future generations of leaders of roe as a title so this term agagite could be lent to future anti-semites i mean if you run into somebody who's real Nazi like and they don't like jewish people today and somebody was like man we use as we throw on the whole literally hitler thing a lot but this dude i was talking to him he literally is trying to be hitler he's hitlerish well okay you would know what was meant by that you would know what set of ideas that encompasses and so it's not crazy to look back at all sorts of different cultures and all sorts of different languages and stories and so forth and say yes some stuff leaves such a big cultural imprint that the thing that left the big cultural imprint just becomes the name the descriptor for anything that resembles it or echoes it in future stories as it gets kind of like how uh... all facial tissues are called clean access and how all sugary soft drink powder mixes or called the kool-aid there's some name for what happens when one particular brand stamps their name on anything that ever resembles it after that i don't know what the name of that phenomenon is now these smart people who settled in their genealogies who are part of the twelve tribes specifically i think chapter four here's about juda and at the end of the chapter says you know these guys when they settled in these places they fought with these people and then right here at the very end it says they killed the remaining a malekite's who had escaped and they have lived there to this day so the suggestion is that who are the remaining malekites uh... i guess they must be referencing the ones who escaped when king sol took his foot off the throttle because he was more interested in plunder then finishing off his enemies as he was instructed to do and so the suggestion is that first chronicles for rounds out the story of the malekites and that's really the last we see of the malekite says an actual tribe right there and then of course in ester when we see aga guy we're talking about someone who is like them who had characteristics like them this is a practice that we see elsewhere in the bible that is
